ygData.subject: NEAT Drummer

Since Colin raised the topic of evolutionary art and music, I thought 
I mi=
ght point out NEAT Drummer for those who haven't already read 
about it. We=
've been developing NEAT Drummer at EPlex over the last 
couple years.

NEA=
T Drummer allows the user to interactively evolve drum tracks for 
existing=
 songs.  You can basically input an instrumental MIDI file 
and it will cre=
ate drums to go with it.  Like a lot of other 
interactive evolution work w=
e've been doing, it's motivated by the 
CPPN theory.  Because music is a te=
mporal pattern, a pattern-
generating representation like CPPNs should be w=
ell-suited to 
generating music. 

However, NEAT Drummer has an interesting=
 trick where it creates the 
drum tracks as a function of preexisting parts=
, which means they are 
patterns that are functions of preexisting patterns=
 that were created 
by human composers.  The effect is that they seem to se=
amlessly 
follow the structure of the song.

Here's a paper on it:

http://=
eplex.cs.ucf.edu/index.php?
option=3Dcom_content&task=3Dview&id=3D14&Itemid=
=3D28#hoover.evomusart08

And some MIDI samples that go with the paper:

ht=
tp://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/neatdrummer/

(drums in all the samples are generated=
 by NEAT Drummer)

Interestingly, even at generation 1 the drum tracks tend=
 to sound 
good because they are constrained by the underlying instrumental=
 
tracks, which already make sense.

ken
